thread.title: Denver Feed-a-Family distribution in jeopardy after money runs dry
thread.title_full: Denver Feed-a-Family distribution in jeopardy after money runs dry - The Denver Post

author: Jesse Paul
title: Denver Feed-a-Family distribution in jeopardy after money runs dry
text:
Denver's Feed-a-Family distribution over Thanksgiving may be suspended this year because of a lack of money, the Epworth Foundation announced this week.
The foundation say a loss of a major corporate sponsor and increased food costs are putting the annual program in honor of "Daddy" Bruce Randolph at risk.
The distribution provides more than 8,000 Thanksgiving baskets annually.
Foundation leaders are slated to talk about the shortage and lack of funding at a news conference Tuesday morning.
"Daddy" Bruce Randolph fed the needy and homeless for free on Thanksgiving through his Denver barbecue joint and the goodness of his heart.
Bruce died in 1994 at the age of 94, but his generosity lived on. Last year, 64,000 people enjoyed a traditional turkey meal with all of the trimmings thanks to the program.
The Epworth Foundation took over the Thanksgiving program in 1994 after Randolph died.
Jesse Paul: 303-954-1733, jpaul@denverpost.com or @JesseAPaul
